PlasmoMAPI 0.1.0
  • Functions

basic_tutorial

Bob Verity and Keith Fraser

2020-02-06

basic_tutorial.Rmd

The purpose of PlasmoMAPI is to use pairwise data on spatial and genetic distances between populations to identify areas that are likely barriers or corridors of gene flow. It does this by comparing the observed distribution of relatedness to what we would expect under the null hypothesis of no systematic spatial pattern in the data.

This vignette is designed to give a flavour of how PlasmoMAPI works and what outputs it can produce. For a more detailed tutorial, including suggestions on how to ensure your results are statistically valid, see the next vignette.

Creating a project and loading data

PlasmoMAPI works using projects, which are essentially just lists containing all data, input and outputs in one place.

Next we need some data to work with. PlasmoMAPI requires two types of data: i) spatial coordinates (longitude and latitude) of sampling locations, ii) pairwise statistical values between all sampling locations - most likely estimates of genetic relatedness. For this vignette we will use a dataset stored within the package. These data were simulated under a simple model of genetics and migration, and crucially with a known barrier and a known corridor of gene flow that we will try to identify.
